subject: Art
title: Blending Acrylics
description: Techniques for smooth gradients despite fast drying time.

hook.text: The biggest acrylic complaint: 'It dries too fast to blend!' True â€” but there are techniques that create smooth transitions despite the speed. The key is working WITH the fast drying, not against it.

buildup.text: Blending methods: 1) Work fast with large brushes (beat the drying). 2) Use retarder medium (slows drying 15-30 minutes). 3) Mist with a spray bottle (keeps the surface workable). 4) Wet-on-dry layering (small overlapping strokes).

discovery.text: Optical blending: instead of physically blending two colors, place small strokes of each color side by side. From a distance, the eye blends them. The Impressionists used this â€” it creates vibrant, lively transitions.

twist.text: Dry-brush blending: load a dry brush with a tiny bit of paint and scrub it over the transition area. The paint catches on the texture of the canvas, creating a natural, broken blend that looks more interesting than a perfect gradient.

climax.text: Create a smooth gradient from blue to yellow using four different methods: fast wet blending, retarder-assisted blending, optical (small strokes side by side), and dry-brush. Each produces a different quality of transition.

punchline.text: You don't need slow paint to blend. You need the right technique for the right moment.

quiz.question: What is 'optical blending' in painting?
options: Placing small strokes of different colors side by side so the eye mixes them at a distance
